note.text: Yesterday Cliff (ParisXArt) sent me a voice message saying how much he liked the album. Today I put together 5 songs that are in progress for us to collaborate on. He'll be in the studio Monday.
I ordered a custom hoodie with the text "Team Allison." on it. I specifically got it on a 4000ind blank after doing some research. Seems like those are the super thick ones I like.
Fiddling with the update_diary script and automating the commit changes.
Listened to an episode of revisionist history with Al about democratic lotteries. Al said someone presented on that topic to her PhD group. I wonder what else fits that criteria.
Need some new jeans.
What is freedom and how is it different from power or agency?
Mode collapse: when the generator in a GAN just produces the same high scoring output to feed into the discriminator.
Cycle GAN solves the problem of mode collapse by introducing another GAN that takes the generated output and tries to detect if it's a valid input of the first GAN.

We can derive the formula for the area of a circle, pi*r^2 by slicing the circle into several concentric rings. Then we take each of those rings and lay down out flat. We can approximate the area of those rings as the length of the ring (2*pi*t) multiplied by the height, which is the slice interval (dr). When we lay all of the slices together they form a triangle with area r(2*pi*r)/2.

Sin(x) is the distance above the origin of we go x distance along the arc of the unit circle. Cos(x) is the distance to the right of the origin. So if we go pi/2 we've travelled from the right of the circle to the top of the circle so sin(pi/2) is 1. When we are the right of the unit circle x=0 since we haven't travelled anywhere and cos(0) = 1.
The d(sin(x)) = cos(x)

Added AlleleCount type to rust genomics. Basically a way to represent NA that plays nicely with calculations. Seems like I'll need to add an AlleleFreq type as well. I wonder if there is a way to do this with Option types instead. I don't think so since the compiler can't reason about adding traits you didn't define to types you didn't define so I think I need to make a brand spanking new type.
Specie is money in the form of coins rather than notes.

Nathan Tankus’s news letter today talked about the need for congress to extend the unemployment boost. One thing I never thought about was that with people getting kicked out of houses, maintenance of the house is decreased and that could lead to breeding grounds for mosquitos. There are many externalities that I haven’t considered.

I got up a little later than usual. Stayed in bed read emails. Unsubscribes from a few lists, chessable, some rapper from Brooklyn. The dog started whining at 9:45. What's funny is she's not whining to be walked or fed, although she would love that, she's whining for someone to come out and hang. She'll stop whining if you just sit in the same room as her. Nathan Tankus's newsletter just popped in my inbox. I think I'll feed the dog, read it while she's eating, then take her for a walk before it gets to hot.
It seems that ass the US slides towards brave new world Hong Kong slides towards 1984

soup (v.)

"increase the horsepower of an engine," 1921, probably from soup (n.) in slang sense of "narcotic injected into horses to make them run faster" (1911), influenced by supercharge (v.).
Brushed up on some pretty basic trig. Felt pretty good. The goal is to reteach myself enough math to really grok machine learning and stats papers.

Didn’t do any serious programing today. I did find out that cron doesn’t have access to the git credentials. Might have to setup a different user, configure it with my credentials, or try another method. Think I’ll read some of the pytorch book.

After brushing up on my integration skills, its super obvious that starlings approximation for the natural log of a factorial is in part just the integral of the natural log of that number (without the factorial). Again this seems super obvious when you take into account that multiplication becomes addition in ln and that adding many numbers together is like doing an integral. It also explains why the approximation gets better for larger n. It might also explain that weird error correcting term.

The PMF of the binomial distribution is actually really easy to remember if you work through it logically. Lets first look at the binomial coefficient, n choose x. This is the number of ways we can pick x objects from n objects. For example, if we are flipping a coin 10 times. 10 choose 3 is the number of ways we could get 3 heads out of that sequence. Great so we have the number of events in the event space that we want to count. Next up, what is the probability of those events? Lets say p is the probability of a success on any given trial. Then if X = 3 and n = 10 we need to have p*p*p or p^3 success and (1-p)^7 failures. The odds of both of those happening (multiply them together) is the odds of one of our events under consideration. So if we multiply that by the number of events we should get the probability of flipping exactly 3 heads over 10 flips. Brilliant. To recap thats (n choose x)*(p^x)*(1-p)^(n-x).
Grinded through my backlog of anki cards while going through the proof for any cards I got wrong. Mostly the derivative of inverse trig functions.
Split first in a 12 person poker tournament today. I made less than my hourly rate I think but hey, it was fun.
Matt Levine’s news letter today talked about how vaccine trial results and airline stocks are very correlated and the ramifications wrt insider trading.

Cycle GAN solves the problem of mode collapse by introducing another GAN that takes the generated output and tries to detect if it's a valid input of the first GAN.

We can derive the formula for the area of a circle, pi*r^2 by slicing the circle into several concentric rings. Then we take each of those rings and lay down out flat. We can approximate the area of those rings as the length of the ring (2*pi*t) multiplied by the height, which is the slice interval (dr). When we lay all of the slices together they form a triangle with area r(2*pi*r)/2.

Sin(x) is the distance above the origin of we go x distance along the arc of the unit circle. Cos(x) is the distance to the right of the origin. So if we go pi/2 we've travelled from the right of the circle to the top of the circle so sin(pi/2) is 1. When we are the right of the unit circle x=0 since we haven't travelled anywhere and cos(0) = 1.
The d(sin(x)) = cos(x)

I wonder if there is a way to do this with Option types instead. I don't think so since the compiler can't reason about adding traits you didn't define to types you didn't define so I think I need to make a brand spanking new type.
